items.title: Python 3.9: undefined symbol: Py_GetArgcArgv in setproctitle
items.body:
Fedora 33 is built against (at this moment pre-release?) Python 3.9, and we
have problems with linking of the compiled setproctitle:
```
>>> import setproctitle
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ImportError: /usr/lib64/python3.9/site-packages/setproctitle.cpython-39-x86_64-linux-gnu.so: undefined symbol: Py_GetArgcArgv
```
That symbol isn't exported in the new libpython 3.9 version.  For more info:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1792059

items.title: Add to README about python-prctl
items.body:
https://github.com/seveas/python-prctl

it has 

```
prctl.set_name(process_name)
prctl.set_proctitle(process_name)
```

but both are not portable. Also this library does not support Python 3.8 yet. And the more important -- it is not packaged in Fedora.

Rgrs,

Max

items.title: Does this package follow semantic versioning?
items.body:
Does this package follow [semantic versioning](https://semver.org) ([PEP 440](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0440/#semantic-versioning))? 
Is it safe to use ~= requirement operator?
```
setproctitle~=1.1.10
```

items.title: Not working with PyInstaller
items.body:
I'm not sure if this issue is in `setproctitle` but when I try to use it with a bundled app using PyInstaller it is just not working.

Here is a simple example:
sample.py

```
import setproctitle

print setproctitle.getproctitle()
setproctitle.setproctitle("test")
print setproctitle.getproctitle()
```
output:
```
arossert$ python sample.py
python sample.py
test
```

Then I use PyInstaller
`pyinstaller sample.py`

Running the code:
```
arossert$ dist/sample/sample


```
Output is empty

Tested on MacOS.

items.title: Unable to install in cygwin
items.body:
On `cygwin` 64bit, I wasn't able to install with Python 2.7, 3.6, 3.7.
I ran the command `pythonX.Y -m pip install setproctitle` and recieved an error:
```
gcc -shared -Wl,--enable-auto-image-base build/temp.cygwin-3.0.7-x86_64-3.6/src/setproctitle.o build/temp.cygwin-3.0.7-x86_64-3.6/src/spt_debug.o build/temp.cygwin-3.0.7-x86_64-3.6/src/spt_setup.o build/temp.cygwin-3.0.7-x86_64-3.6/src/spt_status.o build/temp.cygwin-3.0.7-x86_64-3.6/src/spt_strlcpy.o -L/usr/lib/python3.6/config -L/usr/lib -lpython3.6m -o build/lib.cygwin-3.0.7-x86_64-3.6/setproctitle.cpython-36m-x86_64-cygwin.dll
build/temp.cygwin-3.0.7-x86_64-3.6/src/spt_setup.o: In function `get_argc_argv':
/tmp/pip-install-h24jpxug/setproctitle/src/spt_setup.c:373: undefined reference to `Py_GetArgcArgv'
/tmp/pip-install-h24jpxug/setproctitle/src/spt_setup.c:373:(.text+0xc9): relocation truncated to fit: R_X86_64_PC32 against undefined symbol `Py_GetArgcArgv'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1
```
`python-dev` is installed for each of the versions.
It happens with source code as well.

It appears to be related to the python's function `Py_GetArgcArgv` which is declared internally only. I was able to fix this by one of the following ways:
1. Comment out the line https://github.com/dvarrazzo/py-setproctitle/blob/d6a43b14470d806984d03079164ba05cebb997d0/src/spt_setup.c#L373
2. Creating a new `spt_python.c` file, with an implementation of the function. It doesn't return anything.

Both ways are basic and needs a better solution.

items.title: Setting title fails sometimes
items.body:
This works:

```python
import setproctitle
title = setproctitle.getproctitle()
log.debug("current title: %s", title)
setproctitle.setproctitle("filedb web server - " + str(title))
```

If we change the hyphen to a colon, it doesn't work (the title remains unchanged):


```python
import setproctitle
title = setproctitle.getproctitle()
log.debug("current title: %s", title)
setproctitle.setproctitle("filedb web server: " + str(title))
```

Version: Python 3.7.0 (default, Sep 15 2018, 19:13:07) [GCC 8.2.1 20180831] on linux  
Running on Arch AMD64

items.title: need to set command name (/proc/nn/comm) separate to title
items.body:
It needs to be possible to set the command name for the linux process separately to the process title.

I tried to use setproctitle to simply remove the python3 prefix from the name in ps; eg
```
/path/to/python3 /some/path/to/my/script.py arg1 arg2
```
using
```
setproctitle(' '.join([os.path.realpath(__file__)] + sys.argv[1:]))
```
However, any use of setproctitle also changes what linux has in `/proc/<pid>/comm`, which is the command name and apparently limited to ~16 characters. Normally it is the name of the executable without any path eg bash, python3, apache2.

After using setproctitle with the above, `/proc/.../comm` reads `'/some/path/to/'` ie the first 16 characters of the process title.

items.title: Implement a function to change thread title
items.body:
**george** *16:31*
```
/home/george/.config/hexchat/logs/Gambit/#gambithumans.log:2016-04-11T13:38:08
<piro>   yes, setproctitle changes the process title, not the thread. I don't know where
does htop take its visualization... if it's possible to change the thread title it woudl
be interesting to do so
```
It seems to be possible. From prctl (2):
```
       PR_SET_NAME (since Linux 2.6.9)
              Set the name of the calling thread, using the value in the location
              pointed to by (char *) arg2.  The name can be up to 16 bytes long,
              and should be null-terminated if it contains fewer bytes.
              This is the same attribute that can be set via pthread_setname_np(3)
              and retrieved using pthread_getname_np(3).  The attribute is likewise
              accessible via /proc/self/task/[tid]/comm, where  tid is the name of the
              calling thread.
```
SO link: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2369738/can-i-set-the-name-of-a-thread-in-pthreads-linux
	
**piro** *18:12*
mmm
`setproctitle.setthreadtitle()` then...

items.title: Importing setproctitle changes argv
items.body:
Importing setproctitle changes argv in unexpected ways. 
Test case attached.
[test_setproctitle.zip](https://github.com/dvarrazzo/py-setproctitle/files/306097/test_setproctitle.zip)

Before import:
argv[0]: ./test_setproctitle
argv[1]: 1
argv[2]: 2
argv[3]: 3

After import:
argv[0]: ./test_setproctitle 1 2 3
argv[1]: 1 2 3
argv[2]: 2 3
argv[3]: 3

This is related to #45 and #46. But it is also different. 
This was very hard to find (took me 1 day). Also, it is a show stopper. Thus, the severity is quite high (for me).
Tested with 1.1.7 and 1.1.10.

items.title: Just importing setproctitle impacts name
items.body: See https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1238841, it sounds like just importing the module changes the process name. It should only change the process name when `setproctitle()` is called.

items.title: Just importing setproctitle affected /proc/{pid}/comm
items.body:
I've observed that `/proc/pid/comm` is changed during `spt_setup`, which is invoked in INIT_MODULE.
I think we'd better off leaving it unchanged until `setproctitle` or `getproctitle` is called.

items.title: Compilation fails on alpine linux 3.2
items.body:
I'm running into the following issue when installing on alpine 3.2 (docker https://hub.docker.com/_/alpine/):

```
 /usr/include/linux/prctl.h:133:8: error: redefinition of 'struct prctl_mm_map'
     struct prctl_mm_map {
            ^
    In file included from src/spt_status.c:57:0:
    /usr/include/sys/prctl.h:88:8: note: originally defined here
     struct prctl_mm_map {
            ^
    error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1
```

Removing line https://github.com/dvarrazzo/py-setproctitle/blob/d346abbce4c554404a1447daf6e8e0822d6491a0/src/spt_status.c#L58 seems to fix this.

items.title: Document that you want to import setproctitle before modules calling setenv
items.body: See issue #42

items.title: setproctitle fails if you have imported numpy
items.body:

$

items.title: RPM build fails with "python setup.py bdist_rpm" command
items.body: Originally submitted by **guimbaue** as **issue 32**: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. run python setup.py bdist_rpm in the top source directory. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? It should generate RPMs in the ./dist folder, it fails to find some source files. What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? setproctitle 1.1.8 Please provide any additional information below. The fix is just include all src files from the src/\* folder in the MANIFEST files. I propose a patch (attached) where I removed the MANIFEST file and added the MANIFEST.in file with "include src/*" rule.

items.title: Pylint error when importing from setproctitle
items.body: Originally submitted by **Seth.T.Rosenblum** as **issue 31**: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1.Create a python script with the line "from setproctitle import setproctitle" 2.Install pylint 1.1.0 3.run pylint against your script with rule E0611 enabled What is the expected output? What do you see instead? It should pass no problem, but you see: [E0611(no-name-in-module), ] No name 'setproctitle' in module 'setproctitle' What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? 1.1.8 on various OSs with python 2.7. Please provide any additional information below. This might be a bug with the way python deals with c-defined libraries, but it seemed like something you guys could more easily figure out.

items.title: MANIFEST.in file not present in pypi zip/tarball (@ v 1.1.8)
items.body:
Originally submitted by **jrocnuck** as **issue 30**:

I'm trying to create setproctitle rpms using pypi2rpm but with the latest release (1.1.8), the MANIFEST.in file does not exist in the package archive here https://pypi.python.org/pypi/setproctitle.

Could the MANIFEST.in file be modified to actually include the MANIFEST.in file with the package archive when pushed up to pypi please.

This will solve the issues with pypi2rpm and any other tools that require the full source dist (sdist).

items.title: Python embedding tests should be skipped on PyPy
items.body:
Originally submitted by **mgorny@gentoo.org** as **issue 24**:

PyPy doesn't provide a Python library and makes it impossible to build programs embedding Python. Therefore, the 'pyrun' test program can't be built for PyPy and test_embedded\* always fails.

I would suggest either:

1) skipping test_embedded\* if PyPy is being used,

2) or skipping test_embedded\* if 'pyrun' is not available (instead of throwing an error).

items.title: Support setting values for command line arguments separately
items.body: Originally submitted by **vkoukis** as **issue 23**: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Do this inside Python: import setproctitle; setproctitle.setproctitle('exec arg1 arg2') What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Everything looks ok in ps: vkoukis 32321 32287 3 12:54 pts/3 00:00:00 exec arg1 arg2 But not in /proc/32321/cmdline: $ cat /proc/32321/cmdline exec arg1 arg2 The problem is that arguments should be separated from the actual name of the executable by NUL bytes, e.g.: $ hexdump -vC /proc/32137/cmdline 00000000 2f 75 73 72 2f 73 62 69 6e 2f 61 70 61 63 68 65 |/usr/sbin/apache| 00000010 32 00 2d 6b 00 73 74 61 72 74 00 |2.-k.start.| 0000001b Otherwise one cannot tell apart the name of the executable from the rest of the arguments. When trying to use NUL bytes expicitly: ## In [7]: setproctitle.setproctitle('exec\x00arg1\x00') TypeError Traceback (most recent call last) /home/vkoukis/<ipython console> in <module>() TypeError: argument 1 must be string without null bytes, not str What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? I am using the package that comes with Debian Squeeze: $ dpkg -l python-setproctitle Desired=Unknown/Install/Remove/Purge/Hold | Status=Not/Inst/Conf-files/Unpacked/halF-conf/Half-inst/trig-aWait/Trig-pend |/ Err?=(none)/Reinst-required (Status,Err: uppercase=bad) ||/ Name Version Description +++-=====================-=====================-========================================================== ii python-setproctitle 1.0.1-1 A setproctitle implementation for Python Please provide any additional information below. I think it would make sense to support setting the names of command-line arguments explicitly, either by supporting an arbitrary number of arguments, e.g. setproctitle('exec', 'arg1', 'arg2'), or by allowing NUL bytes inside the string.

What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Expected out is a completed build. However the build fails with the following, src/spt_setup.c: In function 'spt_setup': src/spt_setup.c:469:5: error: 'rv' undeclared (first use in this function) This also happened with easy_install setproctitle. What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? This is version 1.1.5 with Pythonxy-2.7.2.1 on Windows XP Please provide any additional information below. items.title: Windows VC++ builds not supported out-of-the-box
items.body: Originally submitted by **kriswempa** as **issue 20**: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Start a Visual Studio 2008 command prompt 2. Run "python setup.py install" What is the expected output? What do you see instead? I expected the module to be built and installed without any errors. Instead, there are several problems. Instead, there are fatal errors starting with this: c:\VS9\VC\BIN\amd64\cl.exe /c /nologo /Ox /MD /W3 /GS- /DNDEBUG -DSPT_VERSION=1. 1.4b1 -IK:\Toolchains\Windows7\X64\sig1\Python-2.7.1\include -IK:\Toolchains\Win dows7\X64\sig1\Python-2.7.1\PC /Tcsrc/spt_setup.c /Fobuild\temp.win-amd64-2.7\Re lease\src/spt_setup.obj spt_setup.c src/spt_setup.c(21) : warning C4273: '_environ' : inconsistent dll linkage c:\VS9\VC\INCLUDE\stdlib.h(317) : see previous definition of '_environ' src/spt_setup.c(40) : error C2143: syntax error : missing ';' before 'type' src/spt_setup.c(43) : error C2143: syntax error : missing ';' before 'type' src/spt_setup.c(44) : error C2143: syntax error : missing ';' before 'type' src/spt_setup.c(46) : error C2065: 'src' : undeclared identifier What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? 1.1.4b1 Please provide any additional information below. The first error is caused by variables being declared in the middle of a code block, which is supported only under C++ (not C). However, the offending code is not supposed to be getting compiled under Windows. The 2 main problems I found are described below. (1) The macro which controls this conditional compilation is incorrect. The MS VC++ compiler sets "_WIN32" automatically. The macro being used in the code is "WIN32". Therefore, this either needs to be changed to "_WIN32" or the setup.py file needs to be modified to set "WIN32" for Windows platforms. (2) In spt_status.c, the "#include <unistd.h>" line needs a conditional so that it is not processed on Windows systems. The fix for this is to make it conditional upon either _WIN32 or WIN32 (depending on which fix is used for #1)

items.title: Process name unchanged in /proc/PID/status
items.body:
Originally submitted by **calumlind** as **issue 18**:

I was looking to implement setproctitle in Deluge but am unable to get /proc/PID/status set to the same value as /proc/PID/ so that `ps c` matches `ps a`.

I saw there was a similar problem in issue #15 and so include the tests you were asking for there. 

These are the values before using setproctitle:
    $ cat /proc/PID/cmdline
        /usr/bin/python /usr/bin/deluge
    $ head -1 /proc/PID/status
        Name:   /usr/bin/deluge

and after setting title to 'deluge':
    $ cat /proc/PID/cmdline
        deluge
    $ head -1 /proc/PID/status
        Name:   /usr/bin/deluge

I see no issue when setting title in a simple python script and your example returns the same result:
    $ python -c "from ctypes import *; cdll.LoadLibrary('libc.so.6').prctl(15, byref(create_string_buffer('hello world')), 0, 0, 0); print open('/proc/self/status').readline()"
        Name:   hello world

setproctitle 1.1.3
Ubuntu 11.10 Oneiric 3.0.0-14-generic

items.title: problem in scientific linux
Doesn't work on FreeBSD?
items.body:
Originally submitted by **ec@1calendar.dk** as **issue 14**:

I tried this on FreeBSD 8.2:

% python freebsd_nosetproc.py &
[1] 47649
% python freebsd_setproc.py &
[2] 47650
% ps -axo 'pid,comm,args' | grep python
47649 python        python freebsd_nosetproc.py
47650 python        python: helloworld (python)

I was under the impression that setproctitle() would change the command name, not just the command arguments.

freebsd_setproc.py:

   from setproctitle import setproctitle
   import time
   setproctitle('helloworld')
   time.sleep(10)

freebsd_nosetproc.py just sleeps and exits.

I tried starting the script directly, with a shebang at the top of the file, but with the same results.

items.title: something not working with python -m
items.body: Originally submitted by **daniele.varrazzo** as **issue 8**: Reported by Raymond Rizzuto. Confirmed on Ubuntu with Python 2.6. What steps will reproduce the problem? $ cat test.py import setproctitle print setproctitle.getproctitle() $ python -m test What is the expected output? python -m test What do you see instead? python - the process title in /proc/PID/cmdline reads as "python -\x00\x00test\x00" The result is not fixed after using setproctitle(): $ cat test2.py import setproctitle setproctitle.setproctitle('012345678901234') print "proctitle", setproctitle.getproctitle() print "cmdline", repr(open("/proc/self/cmdline").read()) $ python -t test2.py # this works proctitle 012345678901234 cmdline '012345678901234\x00\x00\x00\x00' $ python -m test2 # this not proctitle 01234567 cmdline '01234567\x00\x00test2\x00'

items.title: extension header files missing from MANEFEST causes setup.py bdist_rpm to fail
items.body: Originally submitted by **csears** as **issue 7**: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. extract setproctitle-0.2 somewhere from the tar.gz 2. run 'python setup.py bdist_rpm' What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Expected the RPM to build without errors. Instead I get this... running build_ext building 'setproctitle' extension creating build creating build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.6 creating build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.6/src gcc -pthread -DNDEBUG -O2 -g -pipe -Wall -Wp,-D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -fexceptions -fstack-protector --param=ssp-buffer-size=4 -m64 -mtune=generic -D_GNU_SOURCE -fPIC -O2 -g -fPIC -DHAVE_SYS_PRCTL_H=1 -DSPT_VERSION=0.2 -I/usr/include/python2.6 -c src/setproctitle.c -o build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.6/src/setproctitle.o src/setproctitle.c:16:24: error: spt_status.h: No such file or directory src/setproctitle.c: In function âspt_setproctitleâ: src/setproctitle.c:45: warning: implicit declaration of function âset_ps_displayâ src/setproctitle.c:45: error: âtrueâ undeclared (first use in this function) src/setproctitle.c:45: error: (Each undeclared identifier is reported only once src/setproctitle.c:45: error: for each function it appears in.) src/setproctitle.c: In function âspt_getproctitleâ: src/setproctitle.c:64: warning: implicit declaration of function âget_ps_displayâ src/setproctitle.c:64: warning: assignment makes pointer from integer without a cast src/setproctitle.c: In function âinitsetproctitleâ: src/setproctitle.c:136: warning: implicit declaration of function âsave_ps_display_argsâ src/setproctitle.c:140: warning: implicit declaration of function âinit_ps_displayâ error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1 error: Bad exit status from /var/tmp/rpm-tmp.H9Niar (%build) RPM build errors: Bad exit status from /var/tmp/rpm-tmp.H9Niar (%build) error: command 'rpmbuild' failed with exit status 1 What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? setproctitle-0.2 on Fedora 12 Please provide any additional information below. Adding the extension header files to the MANEFEST fixed the problem for me. Here's the patch... # diff setproctitle-0.2/MANIFEST setproctitle-0.2-fixed/MANIFEST 5a6,8 > src/c.h > src/spt_config.h > src/spt_status.h

items.title: Provide an interface to read the titles of the running processes on Windows
items.body:
Originally submitted by **daniele.varrazzo** as **issue 5**:

I Only know it can be done (see Process Explorer [1]), but how, I don't know.

Also, I wouldn't know if it should be a graphical interface (displaying
processes in a tree, allowing to send them signal etc.) or a command line
tool. I suppose the first would be more useful from a windows user PoV but
more complex to write and with fat dependencies.

Contributions are welcome.

items.title: Trailing white-space isn't cleaned up properly
items.body:
Originally submitted by **bugs@bergstroem.nu** as **issue 2**:

If you use setproctitle with a _huge_ initial argv, it will allocate the entire 
initial length of that argv and fill it with "spaces" (\0 et al) instead of "clearing" 
it. This is very apparent in http://github.com/rtyler/spawning which passes 
config through its argv.

Confirmed on both Linux (2.6.30) and OS X 10.6. I'm only able to reproduce 
on Linux now though - see attached file.
